story:
Once upon a time, in a small village in Kenya, there was a young girl named Nia. Nia was a kind and curious girl who loved to explore the world around her. She would often wander through the fields and forests near her home, discovering new and exciting things every day.

One day, Nia was walking through the woods when she came across a small, injured bird. The bird had a broken wing and couldn't fly. Nia knew she had to help, so she gently picked up the bird and brought it home with her.

Nia's mother was a talented healer, and she knew just what to do to help the injured bird. She carefully set the bird's wing and wrapped it in a soft cloth. Nia was so happy to see the bird getting better, and she spent every day caring for it and keeping it company.

As the bird healed, Nia and her new friend grew closer and closer. They would spend hours together, with Nia telling the bird stories and the bird singing beautiful songs in return. Nia's heart swelled with joy every time she was with her feathered friend.

Finally, the day came when the bird's wing was fully healed and it was time for it to fly away. Nia was sad to see her friend go, but she knew it was for the best. With a heavy heart, she opened the window and watched as the bird took to the sky, soaring higher and higher until it was just a tiny speck in the distance.

But as she watched the bird disappear, Nia realized that she had gained something special from her time with the bird. She had learned the joy of caring for someone else and the happiness that comes from making a difference in the world.

From that day on, Nia made it her mission to help anyone or anything in need, just as she had helped the injured bird. And she lived happily ever after, knowing that she was making the world a better place, one act of kindness at a time.

As Nia snuggled under her blankets and drifted off to sleep, she dreamed of all the wonderful things she would do to help others. And she knew that, just like the bird, she could fly high and make a difference in the world.

The end. Goodnight my dear.
